I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2002 Country Programming Review Mission, the Government of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) reconfirmed its request to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  prepare  an  environmental  improvement  project  for 
managing wastewater and controlling pollution and floods in Fuzhou City, capital of Fujian 
Province (Map 1). The ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC in October 2002 and reached 
an  understanding  with  the  Fujian  provincial  government  (FPG)  and  Fuzhou  municipal 
government  (FMG)  on  the  goals,  purpose,  outputs,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and 
implementation arrangements for the TA.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Wastewater disposal has historically been achieved through septic tanks, with effluents 
discharged to the inland river and canal system.  Rapid development and increased population 
density have caused heavy pollution and frequent flooding of rivers and canals in urban areas. 
The results are odor, nuisance, and high risk to health, particularly from waterborne diseases. 
The Government has recognized that adequate environmental protection and pollution controls 
are  essential  preconditions  for  sustainable  economic  growth.  One  of  the  Government’s 
development objectives is to improve the quality of the urban environment and to integrate 
environmental planning with economic and social development efforts. Government policies 
require that urban environmental pollution and ecological damage be controlled by 2010. State 
guidelines require that major cities, such as provincial capitals, have a wastewater treatment 
rate of 70% by the year 2010.2 However, many cities do not have adequate wastewater 
treatment facilities to improve the quality of discharge into rivers and lakes. 
 
3.  The rivers in Fuzhou City are highly polluted due to inadequate treatment of wastewater 
discharge. Expanding the sewer network and wastewater treatment capacity is urgently needed 
to improve environmental conditions in Fuzhou, and raise water quality in the local water 
courses from the current Class V to Class IV.3 FPG and FMG have resolved to implement 
wastewater collection and treatment so as to achieve or improve on the State guidelines. 
Accordingly both sewage collection networks and wastewater treatment facilities have been 
constructed (or are in the process of being completed) through the ADB-financed Fuzhou Water 
Supply and Wastewater Treatment Project,4 but further coverage and capacities are required. 
The Project proposed by FMG will be an essential component in realizing Fuzhou’s medium-  
and long-term wastewater management programs.  
 
4.  Fuzhou City is currently served by the Xiangban wastewater treatment plant (WTP) with 
a capacity of 50,000 cubic meters (m3)/day and, effective from the end of 2002,  by Yangli 
phase I WTP with a capacity of 200,000 m3/day (Map 2).5 A second phase (Yangli phase II) to

2 
provide an additional capacity of 100,000 m3/day is planned. The adjacent area of Nantai Island, 
which  is  designated  in  the  Fuzhou  City  Master  Plan6  for  rapid  urban  development  to 
accommodate the domestic and industrial growth of Fuzhou, will be served by two new WTPs. 
The Jinshan WTP with a design capacity of 50,000 m3/day is under construction and a  new 
WTP at Lianban with an initial capacity of 150,000 m3/day, increasing to 400,000 m3/day in the 
future, is being planned. It is proposed that the Yangli phase II and Lianban WTPs be developed 
under build, operate, transfer (BOT) principles or other similar models, and that the operation of 
Yangli phase I be transferred to the private sector. The planned introduction of private sector 
participation in wastewater treatment is new in Fujian. Inward experience will be needed for 
establishing BOT or other similar models for WTPs to ensure open tendering procedures, value 
for money, and meeting the necessary targets and guarantees.   
 
5.  Sewer pipes have been laid to serve the existing Xiangban WTP and the new Yangli 
phase I WTP under the new road network as it was developed. Accordingly an extensive 
sewerage system exists, but is not fully connected; nor does it cover the entire urban area of 
Fuzhou. Modifications, additions, and extensions to the sewerage network are required to 
rationalize the drainage areas contributing to the respective WTPs, to connect isolated sewer 
lengths, to increase the connection rate to the networks, and to expand the coverage of the 
system to about 90% of the urban subdistricts north of the Min River. The total length of new 
sewers will be approximately 136 kilometers (km); 35 km of existing sewers will be desilted and 
commissioned. The population served will rise from an existing 680,000 to about 905,000. To 
optimize the drainage areas contributing to the Xiangban and Yangli WTPs under the proposed 
expansion of the sewerage system, some of the new areas will need to be connected to 
Xiangban WTP. As Xiangban WTP only has a capacity of 50,000 m3/day, it is planned to 
reverse the pumping discharge such that some sewage currently draining to Xiangban WTP is 
redirected to Yangli WTP (phases I and II).   
 
6.  A similar deficiency in the sewerage system exists on Nantai Island, which used to be 
largely agricultural land. To facilitate the planned urbanization of up to 84 km2 of land under the 
Fuzhou City Master Plan, approximately 110 km of new sewers and four pumping stations are 
to be constructed and about 8 km of existing sewers is to be desilted and commissioned. These 
works will enable the wastewater system to serve a planned population of approximately 
488,000 in 2007 that is expected to grow to 710,000 in 2020.  
 
7.   The natural inland waterways on Nantai Island were formed through scour of fluvial 
deposits by storm runoff. A maze of small drainage meanders and channels was thus formed. 
They have been modified by human activity, including fish farming and waste tipping, such that 
a  fragmented  and  ineffective  drainage  system  now  exists.  Storm  water  runoff  results  in 
widespread flooding, inundating up to 57% of the total land area.7 This situation is exacerbated 
by tidal locking of the existing outlets. To enable the planned urban development program to 
proceed, the Project will (i) rationalize inland drainage by developing 31 channels with a 
planned total length of about 86 km on the existing waterways; (ii) excavate and remove 
approximately 39,000 tons (t) of construction material, 200 t of domestic solid waste, and 10 t of 
industrial waste; (iii) construct stone-lined rectangular channels of varying widths; (iv) resettle 
about 6,000 persons; (v) refurbish and extend, as necessary, 39 existing tidal gates; and (vi) 
rehabilitate five existing and construct six new drainage water pumping stations. 
                                                 
6  Fuzhou City Master Plan 1995–2010, approved by the national government in May 1999. 
7  Total land area, including recently reclaimed land, measures 142 km2. Original land area was 108.7 km2, but 
flooding affects 62.4 km2.

3 
8.  The inland waterways of Nantai Island are extremely polluted.8 The situation will be 
remedied by the proposed sewerage and wastewater treatment systems (paras. 4 and 6) and 
by maintaining a positive flow in the waterways by pumping river water during times of drought. 
 
9.  The completion of wastewater management for the Fuzhou City and inland drainage on 
Nantai Island will satisfy with the requirements for city planning where existing areas are to be 
fully  serviced  and  new  development  areas  provided  with  full  and  effective  infrastructure. 
Residential, commercial, and industrial development is thus encouraged, resulting in improved 
amenities, increased employment, and enhanced living standards.  
 
10.  The conceptual project framework is in Appendix 1. An initial assessment of the social 
and  poverty  impact  of  the  Project  is  in  Appendix  2.  Impacts  on  poverty  will  be  through 
environmental  improvement  and  employment  generation  although  the  Project  will  involve 
significant resettlement. 
 
11.  Environmental improvement and environmental and natural resource management are 
among  ADB’s  strategic  objectives  in  the  PRC.  ADB’s  strategy  for  the  environment  and 
wastewater  sectors  is  focused  on  strengthening  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for 
sustainable  environmental  management,  supporting  integrated  water  and  wastewater 
management, promoting tariff reform, and encouraging the use of cleaner technologies. ADB’s 
poverty  reduction  strategy  for  the  PRC  envisages  a  range  of  measures  including  the 
improvement of urban living conditions by providing safe drinking water and environmental 
protection  and  by  promoting  employment  and  sustainable  growth.  Already  wastewater 
management in Fuzhou City has been significantly improved through the Fuzhou Water Supply 
and Wastewater Treatment Project (footnote 4). The Project will further support FMG’s efforts in 
creating a clean and economically vibrant city for its growing population, including the poor, in 
line with the development objectives of the Government and ADB. 
 
12.  Policy dialogue on environmental and wastewater management issues will continue in 
parallel with the Project to enhance ADB’s effort in the sector and strengthen the Government’s 
capacity to effect water conservation measures, tariff reform, private sector participation, and 
integrated environmental management.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
13.  The project preparatory TA  will  assist  FMG  to  prepare  a  project  suitable  for  ADB 
financing. The TA will assess the technical, environmental, financial, economic, social, and 
institutional feasibility of an investment for (i) completing the second phase of sewerage to the 
urban areas of Fuzhou City; (ii) constructing a sewerage system for the proposed urban areas 
of Nantai Island; (iii) developing an inland waterway network and flood protection measures for 
Nantai Island; and (iv) improving water quality in the urban streams from the current Class V to 
Class IV. The TA will also identify institutional capacity-building measures including introduction 
of private sector participation in wastewater management and policy reforms to ensure the 
sustainability of the Project and related facilities. 
 
14.  The  output  of  the  TA  will  be  workshops  and  a  series  of  reports  recommending 
approaches  necessary  in  achieving  least-cost,  sustainable  solutions  for  environmental 
                                                 
8  The water quality is worse than Class V (see footnote 3).

4 
improvement that will advance the Government’s development master plans and assist in 
improving living conditions, particularly those of the urban poor. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The  TA  will  (i)  review  the  Fuzhou  City  Master  Plan  and  wastewater  management 
programs and justify the proposed project components; (ii) carry out a water demand forecast 
and determine the potential for water conservation management practices within Fuzhou City; 
(iii) assess the present situation and predict future wastewater generation in the urban drainage 
areas; (iv) review and evaluate the technical options proposed by the prefeasibility studies and 
confirm that the project components are the least-cost options in support of the Fuzhou long-
term  development  plans;  (v)  provide  cost  estimates  and  procurement  arrangements  and 
prepare  a  contract  packaging  plan;  (vi)  carry  out  economic  and  financial  analyses;  (vii) 
undertake environmental impact assessment (EIA) and prepare EIA and summary EIA (SEIA) 
reports; (viii) review and update the Government’s land acquisition and resettlement plan (RP) 
and make a summary; (ix) update and analyze, as appropriate, the financial governance and 
financial performance of the FMG and the new companies which will be set up under FMG for 
the construction and management of the project facilities; (x) recommend necessary enterprise 
and sector reforms; (xi) recommend further tariff reforms; (xii) carry out a social survey to 
evaluate the social and poverty impact of the Project, and identify ways to make the Project 
more pro-poor; and (xiii) establish monitoring indicators and a monitoring mechanism.  The TA 
will also help the Government introduce in the private sector BOT or other similar models of 
wastewater treatment, and develop suitable methodologies and procedures for procuring private 
sector contractors.   
 
16.  The major assumptions in and risks to the successful implementation of the TA include 
(i) inadequate counterpart support and performance; (ii) lack of adequate and timely provision of 
necessary data; (iii) delay in submitting required studies; (iv) delay in appointing and mobilizing 
consultants; (v) inadequate performance by the consultants; and (vi) lack of private sector  
interest in participation in the Yangli phase II and Lianban WTPs. Efforts will be made to ensure 
that competent consultants are recruited on time and that performance checks are carried out 
regularly. FMG agreed to provide adequate counterpart support and provide all necessary data 
when required, and to undertake and update all required studies according to a timetable 
agreed upon with ADB. Close coordination among the consultants, executing and implementing 
agencies, and ADB will further mitigate these risks. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $750,000 equivalent, of which $450,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $300,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $600,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$150,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Spain. The Government of PRC has agreed to provide the balance of the local 
currency  cost,  equivalent  to  $150,000,  for  counterpart  staff,  office  space,  furniture, 
administrative support, logistics, and interpretation services. The Government has been advised 
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project.  Details of the 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  FMG will be the executing agency for the TA. A senior official from FPG will chair the 
steering committee for the TA, with members from FPG, FMG, Fujian Finance Bureau, Fuzhou 
Finance  Bureau,  Fujian  Planning  Committee,  Fuzhou  Planning  Bureau,  Fuzhou  Municipal 
Construction Committee, and Fuzhou Urban Management Regulatory Bureau to ensure that 
their views will be adequately considered and necessary support will be provided. The TA office, 
established under Fuzhou Water Supply and Wastewater Treatment Project, will be retained to 
facilitate interdepartmental arrangements and coordination among the concerned ministries and 
departments in the state, provincial, and municipal governments to support the work of the 
consultants. A senior official of FMG will be the TA office director. A full-time qualified and 
experienced senior staff member will be appointed as manager to oversee the implementation 
of the TA. Two full-time counterpart staff with relevant qualifications and experience will be 
assigned  to  assist  the  consultants.  To  facilitate  implementation,  FMG  will  support  the 
consultants by providing a suitably furnished office with utilities and telecommunication access, 
materials, maps, data, and documents required by the TA. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 4.5 months starting in February 2003, with 
expected completion in July 2003. The total input of the consultants is estimated at 38 person-
months: 14 international and 24 domestic. The consultants will provide expertise in wastewater 
and drainage engineering, environmental assessment, economic and financial analyses, social 
and poverty impact assessment, resettlement issues, institutional development, and private 
sector participation. The consultants will be engaged through a firm in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants based on the quality and cost-based selection method 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. The outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. ADB’s simplified technical proposal 
approach will be used in selecting and engaging the consultants.  
 
20.  The consultants will submit to ADB an inception, an interim, a draft final, and a final 
report. In addition, they will submit an EIA and SEIA report, an English translation of the 
Government’s RP, and a summary RP. The executive summary of the interim report, and the 
complete draft final and final reports will be translated into Chinese to facilitate review by the 
Government. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Spain 
for the purpose of preparing the Fuzhou  Environmental Improvement Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China: 
 
Improvements in sewage collection will reduce pollution in open urban waterways, improve living conditions, and 
decrease the incidence of waterborne diseases. Flood alleviation through improvements to the inland waterway 
system and associated pumping facilities will create a better living environment for the residents, particularly the poor 
living along the riverbanks, in Fuzhou City. Increased employment generation by encouraging new high-technology 
enterprises  is  core  to  the  strategy  for  developing  infrastructure  on  Nantai  Island  and  promoting  sustainable 
development in Fuzhou City. The urban poor should benefit directly from the Project through an increase in 
employment opportunities, first during the construction phases and thereafter in tertiary industries.

Appendix 4  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
A.  Review of Medium-  and Long-Term Plans 
1.  The  consultants  will  review  and  analyze  the  medium-  and  long-term  plans  for 
wastewater management in Fuzhou City. In particular, reference will be to the final report 
prepared  under  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  technical  assistance  (TA)1  and  to  the 
prefeasibility reports2 prepared in August 2002 by the Fuzhou Planning Design Institute, the 
Shanghai Municipal Engineering Design Institute, Fuzhou Environmental Protection Research 
Institute, and Fujian Water Conservancy Planning Institute. The scope of works proposed under 
the prefeasibility reports will be analyzed against the background of ongoing work for the ADB-
financed Fuzhou Water Supply and Wastewater Treatment Project;3 the state, provincial, and 
municipal environment and wastewater management programs under the Tenth Five-Year Plan 
(2001-2005); and long-term city planning proposals. Recommendations will be made on the 
suitability of the proposed works. Where necessary, the consultants will recommend changes to 
the scope of works.   
 
2.  The consultants will also review the prefeasibility study report on the dredging and 
environmental improvements to the inland rivers on Nantai Island, including land area use plan, 
flood alleviation schemes, and inland water management targets. The consultants will assess 
the suitability of the proposed works in relation to the Fuzhou City Master Plan 1995-2010 as 
well as to the medium- and long-term development proposals for the island as a whole. The 
consultants will assess the Fuzhou City development plans and justify that the proposed inland 
river improvement scheme is the least-cost option in support of the Fuzhou City Master Plan. 
Recommendations  for  modifications  to  the  proposed  scope  of  work  may  be  offered  as 
appropriate. 
 
B.  Policy Dialogue-Related Activities 
 
3.  Policy  dialogue  is  ongoing  between  ADB  and  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  in 
conjunction with ADB’s urban lending program. To strengthen policy dialogue, the consultants 
will prepare notes—based on discussions with the Fujian provincial government and Fuzhou 
municipal government (FMG)—on (i) integrated environmental planning and management; (ii) 
urban poverty reduction, social protection, and resettlement policies; (iii) cost recovery and tariff 
reform; (iv) water conservation; (v) industrial pretreatment programs, effluent recycling, and 
introduction of clean production techniques; (vi) regulatory enforcement and monitoring; and (vii) 
private sector participation.  
 
C.  Technical Aspects 
 
4.  The consultants will (i) review the sewerage system in Fuzhou City and assess how the 
Project interconnects with the system; (ii) review, reconfirm, or revise the technical options 
proposed by the prefeasibility studies; (iii) identify and assess the domestic, commercial, and 
industrial water demands and resulting wastewater discharges within the urban districts under 
the Project; (iv) assess the diurnal/seasonal variations in discharges and characterize the

5.  The findings of these investigations and reviews will confirm the works as proposed or 
lead to recommendations for modifications. Quality control for the proposed technical options 
under  the  feasibility  study  should  be  emphasised.  Other  aspects  to  be  covered  by  the

instrumentation and controls systems to be included; estimated quantities of major civil works 
items; unit rate for civil works items; manufacturers’ budget quotations for major items of plant 
(pumps etc.); staffing requirements for operation and maintenance (O&M); implementation 
schedules; consulting services inputs needed for project implementation, including institutional 
strengthening and development, engineering design and construction supervision over the 
implementation period; detailed cost estimates (by foreign exchange cost and local currency 
cost) and cost for O&M, following ADB’s guidelines and standards (the consultants should use 
costing models incorporating ADB’s requirements for physical and price contingencies and 
interest during construction); detailed financial plans and disbursement schedule; indicative 
procurement packages; and commissioning procedures and O&M manuals. 
 
6.  For associated wastewater treatment works (not part of the Project but to be developed 
by the private sector), the consultants will review the following: estimated wastewater flows and 
strengths,  including  allowance  for  infiltration  and  storm  water  contribution;  required  plant 
capacity and treatment process; flexibility to accommodate future changes in flow rates or 
standards  in  treated  effluent;  sludge  treatment  and  disposal  methods;  and  phasing  of 
completion to accept sewage flows. 
 
D.  Wastewater Management 
 
7.  The  consultants  will  submit  to  FMG,  the  executing  agency,  evaluations  and 
recommendations on the following: (i)  environmental monitoring systems for influents to the 
sewerage systems to protect the fabric of the sewers and the downstream treatment process; 
(ii) proper technical O&M procedures to ensure efficiency and longer life for the sewers, inland 
waterways, pumping stations, and associated equipment; (iii) proper equipment for sewerage 
system maintenance and inspection; (iv) appropriate equipment and procedures for the safety of 
maintenance workers; (v) strategy for and means of financing a program of sewer connections; 
(vi) collection of data on industrial discharges needed for an industrial pretreatment program; 
(vii) assessment of options and recommendations for operating the proposed project facilities. 
 
E.  Environmental Impact Assessment 
 
8.  To assess the environmental impacts, the consultants will prepare for each component 
an environmental impact assessment (EIA) and a summary environmental impact assessment

Appendix 4  11 
(SEIA)  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Environmental  Assessment  Requirements  (1998)  and 
Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected  Infrastructure  Development  Projects  (1993).  The 
EIA/SEIA will (i) identify and quantify positive and negative environmental impacts associated 
with the project; (ii) identify risks relevant to each component during both construction and 
operation;  and  (iii)  recommend  mitigation  measures  and  an  environmental  management 
program for each component. The environmental issues to be considered will include, but will 
not be limited to, pretreatment of industrial wastes and disposal of excavated and dredged 
materials, storm water retention and flood alleviation measures, resettlement, and construction 
techniques. The consultants will conduct public consultation on the EIA at least twice before 
loan appraisal by ADB, in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy, approved 11 November 
2002. 
 
F.  Financial and Economic Analyses 
 
9.  The consultants will extend the financial and economic analyses presented in the pre-
feasibility studies. The purpose is to assess the economic, financial, and fiscal sustainability of 
the Project; financial viability of the new companies that will be set up for the construction and 
management  of  the  sewerage  systems  and  the  Nantai  Island  environmental  improvement 
project; and the development impact of the components, including the distribution of benefits. 
The proposed components of the Project should be the least-cost  option  based  on  ADB 
Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects.  The financial and economic analyses will be 
undertaken in accordance with ADB’s guidelines4 and models developed by ADB’s Economic 
and Research Department. The consultants will also assess the opportunity cost of flood relief 
and land.  
 
10.  Specifically, the consultants will: (i) review the Fuzhou City Master Plan and wastewater 
treatment programs, including the future demand for wastewater treatment and solid waste 
management, and give the economic justification for these development plans; (ii) analyze the 
cost of all technically feasible alternatives that meet the aim of the development plans and 
propose the least-cost alternative as a component of the Project; (iii) use the COSTAB model to 
analyze  and  summarize  project  costs;  (iv)  review  current  accounting  and  administrative 
capacities,  the  internal  control  system,  and  auditing  procedures;  (v)  establish  financial 
objectives and targets for each component and prepare financing plans and projections and 
other  relevant  financial  statements  for  operations  during  the  20-year  period  after  project 
completion; (vi) in the case of environmental improvement to inland waterways, establish  a 
component financing plan, ongoing maintenance costs, and subsidy schedule; identify the 
beneficiaries of the subsidy and the required funding mechanism for the subsidy in accordance 
with ADB’s criteria for subsidies; (vii) examine the availability of local counterpart funds and 
borrowing commitments; (viii) review tariff levels and structure for each component and assess 
the necessary increase in tariffs and charges in the short and medium term, taking into account 
affordability, willingness to pay, and full cost recovery; (ix) carry out an economic analysis of the 
sewerage network including justification for the treatment plants and an economic analysis of 
drainage improvement including a justification for the Fuzhou City Master Plan, incorporating, to 
the extent possible, economic benefits such as improved water quality for various uses and 
releasing  the  floodplain  for  development;  (x)  identify  potential  project  risks,  introduce  risk

G.  Socioeconomic Analysis 
 
11.  In  focusing  on  social  issues,  the  consultants  will:  (i)  update  the  survey  of  project 
beneficiaries undertaken for the ADB-funded Fuzhou Water Supply and Wastewater Treatment 
Project and extend the survey to cover new areas under the Project (the survey results will be 
disaggregated by gender and income group); estimate the number of project beneficiaries with 
income below the official poverty line in the project areas; conduct affordability analysis; identify 
vulnerable groups including ethnic minority nationalities and indigenous people; and assess any 
impacts and recommend mitigating measures required for these groups; (ii) following ADB’s 
Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Bank Operations, Gender Checklist for 
Water Supply and Sanitation, and Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis, assess the social 
impact of the project income levels and distribution, affordability, including willingness to pay, 
socioeconomic benefits, gender issues and possible negative impacts; (iii) develop a project 
performance  monitoring  system  for  estimating  benefits  and  impacts,  including  relevant 
benchmarks;  and  evaluating  project  performance,  following  ADB’s  guidelines;  (iv)  review 
existing arrangements and procedures for involving beneficiaries and affected people in project 
design and implementation; hold workshops with beneficiaries, affected people, and other 
stakeholders; develop a tailored information and health education campaign with provision for 
monitoring benefits, and prepare programs to promote public awareness and participation; 
document past and expected future public consultation programs; (v) collect and analyze health 
data including the incidence of morbidity and mortality rates due to waterborne diseases; and 
(vi)  evaluate  the  poverty  impact  of  the  Project,  including  the  poverty  impact  ratio  and  a 
statement of the project features relating to poverty reduction. 
 
H.  Resettlement 
 
12.  The consultants will review the Government’s draft resettlement plan (RP) and identify 
modifications  required  to  comply  with  the  PRC’s  Land  Administration  Law,  Implementing 
Regulations,  1998,  ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement,  and  ADB’s  Handbook  on 
Resettlement. In particular the consultants will (i) evaluate the relevant resettlement experience 
available locally; (ii) as part of the socioeconomic baseline survey (para. 11), assess the social 
impact of displaced people and workers; (iii) based on the survey results, identify compensation 
and  rehabilitation  options  and  develop  livelihood  rehabilitation  programs  for  the  displaced 
people; (iv) review the institutional arrangement for distribution of resettlement compensation; 
(v) assist the FMG with refining the RP to include budget, implementation schedule, and 
arrangements for internal and external monitoring and evaluation; (v) assist the FMG to initiate a 
participatory process; and (vi) translate the Government’s RP into the English language and 
prepare a summary RP. 
 
I.  Capacity Building and Training 
 
13.  The consultants will review and assess the existing institutional capacity of the provincial 
and local government departments and agencies responsible for land drainage and wastewater

management, including integration of wastewater and environmental management, capacity for 
financial management and audit requirements, and monitoring and evaluation systems. Based 
on the assessment, the consultants will develop corporate management arrangements and a

15.  The consultants will also advise the FMG on developing private sector participation in 
wastewater treatment. 
 
J.  Project Framework 
 
16.  The consultants, in consultation with government agencies and the project stakeholders, 
will develop a logical project framework that outlines the goal, purposes, outputs, and inputs or 
activities with links to the set of indicators for monitoring project performance. The project 
framework will include measures to enhance the level of participation of the beneficiaries and 
stakeholders in developing the Project. The project framework will be a basis for the project 
performance monitoring system and the risk and sensitivity analyses. The consultants will also 
assist the Government in drawing up the detailed terms of reference for consultants to provide 
project management assistance during implementation of the Project. 
 
K.  Reporting 
 
17.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 4 weeks 
from the start of the TA; (ii) a simplified interim report within 10 weeks from the start of the TA; 
(iii) a draft final report, an EIA/SEIA report, an English translation of the Government’s RP, a 
summary RP and a social and poverty impact assessment report, within 16 weeks from the start 
of the TA; and (iv) a final report 4 weeks after receiving the Government and ADB’s comments 
on the draft final report.  
 
18.  The reports will address all aspects of the terms of reference to the level of detail 
appropriate for the given stage of the TA and include revised project logical frameworks. The 
executive summary of the interim report and the complete draft final and final reports will be 
translated into Chinese. The consultants will present key findings in workshops. Members of the 
steering committee, representatives of the Ministry of Finance and local communities, and ADB 
staff will participate in the workshops and the tripartite meetings, which will be organized after 
the submission and review of the inception report, interim report, and the draft final report.
